node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:

node.text:
Jair Bolsonaro’s actions do not just threaten Brazilian democracy—they have also endangered one of the world’s most important natural resources. 

So why are the right-wing president’s followers still so faithful?

Cover image: Fernando Bizerra Jr/EPA-EFE-Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Polarisation has already damagedA America's global influence Francis Fukuyama'.

node.text:
American power was in decline long before Afghanistan, says Francis Fukuyama. ⁠
⁠
Writing for The Economist, the foreign-policy expert argues that the real challenge to the country’s global standing is not international, but domestic: its political polarisation.⁠
⁠
“American society [...] has found it difficult to find consensus on virtually anything”, he writes. “These conflicts have spread to all aspects of life”, and have “affected foreign policy directly”. ⁠
⁠
The appeal of American institutions and society to people around the world “has been greatly diminished”, he adds.⁠
⁠
America is not likely to regain its earlier power, nor should it aspire to, Mr Fukuyama argues. To find out what he believes the country should do instead, click on the link in our bio, and read the first essay of our By Invitation series on the future of American power.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 18, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'Britain What does the rush into higher-education mean for Britain's universities? RESULTS MANDED OUT IN THE FOLLOWINGROOMS FOLLOWING ROOMS ROOM /33'.

node.text:
Are you starting university next month? If you're in Britain, you'll be one of many.⁠
⁠
The country is witnessing a jump in university attendance. ⁠
⁠
By the end of June 311,000 British 18-year-olds had applied to university, 10% more than last year. ⁠
⁠
But some universities are so over-subscribed that they are offering students money to go elsewhere.⁠
⁠
What explains the higher-education boom, and why is it alarming the government? To find out, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Peter Summers/Getty Images

node.text:
China’s struggle to keep the Delta variant of covid-19 at bay will be felt around the world. ⁠
⁠
Last week the government closed one of the busiest terminals at Ningbo port on China’s east coast when a dockworker was diagnosed with the Delta variant.⁠
⁠
It follows a similar shutdown at Yantian port on China’s south coast in May.⁠
⁠
Unlike other countries, which are learning to live with Delta, China has imposed a hardcore combination of widespread testing and uncompromising quarantines.⁠
⁠
Some experts worry that the shipping delays and the prospect of future shutdowns may even disrupt the West’s Christmas shopping.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read how China’s efforts to battle the virus are compounding an economic slowdown.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 18, 2021. May be a meme of 4 people, beard and text that says 'Asia A Taliban-run Afghanistan will be less isolated than the West may hope'.

node.text:
The question haunting Afghanistan also troubles the outside world: how much have 20 years out of power changed the Taliban? ⁠
⁠
When the Taliban ruled Afghanistan from 1996 to 2001, they were international pariahs. Their hospitality to global jihadists, oppression of women, medieval brutality and cultural vandalism alienated most of the world. ⁠
⁠
Twenty years on, the Taliban seem intent on ensuring that their second regime will be on a sounder diplomatic footing. They have shown they have learned some diplomatic and political finesse, and to tailor their message to the audience.⁠
⁠
Yet a change of style cannot disguise an unchanged ideology; nor a ruthless commitment to enforcing it. America and its allies still have ways to exert influence. Tap the link in our bio to read how.⁠
⁠
Credit: Handout/Getty Images

node.text:
Haiti has been plagued by political turmoil, poverty and natural disasters for years. But they have come in particularly quick succession of late. ⁠
⁠
A 7.2 magnitude earthquake struck Haiti on the morning of August 14th. A tropical storm followed just days later, complicating efforts to help those affected.⁠
⁠
So far more than 1,400 people are confirmed dead—a number that is bound to rise. Thousands more are injured, missing or homeless. ⁠
⁠
The earthquake struck just over a month after the assassination of Jovenel Moïse, the president, on July 7th. Under his ruling gangs proliferated and the economy struggled. ⁠
⁠
Haiti desperately needs a legitimate government, click the link in bio to find out why that may not happen any time soon.

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 18, 2021. May be an image of sky.

node.text:
Wildfires laid waste to woodland across the southern Mediterranean this summer during some of the worst heatwaves in recent history. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The devastation was most severe on the Greek island of Evia, which lies north-east of Athens. Over two weeks the blaze consumed over 50,000 hectares of woodland and razed dozens of homes. Thousands were forced to flee their properties or had their livelihoods destroyed.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
@ayman_oghanna photographed volunteer firefighters in Evia for @1843mag. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“The resilience of the Greek people was inspiring. I think one reason their response was so impressive is because they didn’t expect the state to save them.” ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Spyros, pictured, usually works in a supermarket in the town of Istiaia. When the fires reached his hometown he stopped stacking boxes and picked up a firefighter’s hose. “I just felt that my place needed me”, he says.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now the flames have died down Spyros has become a local hero. “My ex-girlfriend keeps calling me”, he shrugs. But as climate change makes wildfires more common and destructive around the world, this may not be the last time he is called to action.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read how climate change is making wildfires more common.

node.text:
Maggi Hambling is garrulous, witty and gleefully foul-mouthed.⁠
⁠
For most of her career, she has worked primarily as a figurative painter, a latter-day practitioner of the muscular realism pioneered by Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon.⁠ ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read about @1843mag's tennis match with the artist and discover what she thinks of Andy Murray as a subject. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @luisgranena

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Afghanistan. May be an image of 3 people, beard, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
⁠Meet the man expected to be anointed as the leader of the hastily resurrected Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.⁠
⁠
Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar was not among the Taliban men who strode, unopposed, into the presidential palace in Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, on August 15th. But he is credited with getting them there.⁠
⁠
Born into an influential Pushtun tribe in southern Afghanistan in 1968, in his youth Mullah Baradar fought with 'mujahideen' guerrillas against Soviet troops, and the Afghan government they left behind.⁠
⁠
After the war he helped Mullah Muhammad Omar, his former commander, found the Taliban (“students”), who then swiftly conquered much of the country in 1996. ⁠
⁠
After the American invasion in 2001, he and other senior members of the Taliban ran things from Pakistan.⁠
⁠
In 2010 he was tracked down by America’s CIA and arrested. But in 2018, at the request of the Americans, Pakistani officials released him from prison to participate in peace negotiations in Doha.⁠
⁠
In February 2020 it was Mullah Baradar’s signature on an agreement made by America to withdraw its forces.⁠
⁠
Click the link in bio to find out what sort of Afghanistan Mullah Baradar claims to want to build.
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.text:
Of all China’s achievements in the past two decades, one of the most impressive is the rise of its technology industry.⁠
⁠
Alibaba hosts twice as much e­-commerce activity as Amazon does. Tencent runs the world’s most popular super­app, with 1.2bn users.⁠
⁠
That is why Xi Jinping’s assault on tech titans is so startling. ⁠
⁠
The superpower is about to become a policy laboratory in which an unaccountable state wrestles with the world’s biggest firms for control of the 21st century’s essential infrastructure.⁠
⁠
Data are deemed "a factor or product", like land or labour. Some may pass into public ownership.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why the government’s attempt to reshape the technology industry in China is a giant gamble.⁠
⁠
Credit: @guillemcasasus

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business Billions are pouring into the business of decarbonisation'.

node.text:
Wall Street giants and corporate titans are betting on climate innovation.⁠
⁠
New patents related to core technologies like batteries, hydrogen, smart grids and carbon capture are far outpacing those in other technologies, including fossil fuels.⁠
⁠
Money has followed the innovation. Last year investors poured more than $500bn into the “energy transition”, twice as much as in 2010.⁠
⁠
And between 2013 and 2020 venture capital investments in climate tech grew at five times the rate of global startup funding overall. In 2021 these investments may near $60bn in America alone, up from $36bn last year.⁠
⁠
Can this boom give rise to a new blockbuster industry? To read why the modern climate-tech business looks fit and financially sustainable, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @d_urbo_design

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠When Kabul fell to the Taliban, less than 24 hours after President Ashraf Ghani visited the edge of the capital to inspect its defences, it was inevitable that people would try to flee.⁠
⁠
The image that people will remember will be that of an air force transport plane taking off with desperate Afghans clinging to its undercarriage, from which they fell to their deaths.⁠
⁠
The airport is now the only part of the city not held by the militants. Instead, it is defended by several thousand American and other foreign troops, many flown in specifically for the evacuation. ⁠
⁠
Over the coming weeks, the evacuation could lift away tens of thousands of people. And though they have not hindered the evacuation flights, Taliban soldiers are reported to be checking people trying to get into the airport, and preventing many from leaving the country. Thousands of Afghans who might be accepted to fly remain in hiding, wondering if they will be able to escape.⁠
⁠
The last-minute panic to rescue interpreters and others who have worked for foreign armies could have been avoided. Tap the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Shekib Rahmani
